message_1:
In a Centipede game, player A and player B take turns to either "pass" or "take" a coin. The game ends when one player decides to "take" the coin, at which point the other player gets nothing. Both players have common knowledge that the game will end in a finite number of rounds. 

If the game has 5 coins and player A goes first, what strategy should player A use to maximize their outcome in the game? What is the outcome for player A if player B also uses the optimal strategy?
message_2:
In a Centipede game with 5 coins and player A going first, the optimal strategy for player A is to "take" the coin on their first move. This is because if player A passes, player B can then take the coin on their turn, leaving player A with nothing. By taking the coin on the first move, player A guarantees that they will get at least one coin.

If both players use the optimal strategy, the outcome for player A will be 1 coin, as player A takes the first coin and the game ends. Player B will get nothing in this case.
